articles.headline: Emails in Anthony Weiner Inquiry Jolt Hillary Clinton’s Campaign
articles.snippet: The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, told Congress that the emails “appear to be pertinent” to the investigation of Mrs. Clinton’s use of a private server.
articles.abstract: The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, told Congress that the emails “appear to be pertinent” to the investigation of Mrs. Clinton’s use of a private server.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The presidential campaign was rocked on Friday after federal law enforcement officials said that emails pertinent to the closed investigation into Hillary Clinton’s private email server were discovered on a computer belonging to Anthony D. Weiner, the estranged husband of a top Clinton aide.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Supreme Court to Rule in Transgender Access Case
articles.snippet: The question at issue involves a Virginia high school student and a federal directive that effectively expanded a Title IX definition of discrimination.
articles.abstract: The question at issue involves a Virginia high school student and a federal directive that effectively expanded a Title IX definition of discrimination.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday entered the national debate over transgender rights, announcing that it would decide whether a transgender boy may use the boys’ bathroom in a Virginia high school.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak

articles.headline: ‘This Changes Everything’: Donald Trump Exults as Hillary Clinton’s Team Scrambles
articles.snippet: The F.B.I. director’s disclosure of an investigation of new emails interrupted Mrs. Clinton’s momentum as Mr. Trump and other Republicans sought to take advantage.
articles.abstract: The F.B.I. director’s disclosure of an investigation of new emails interrupted Mrs. Clinton’s momentum as Mr. Trump and other Republicans sought to take advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Everything was looking up for Hillary Clinton. She was riding high in the polls, even seeing an improvement on trustworthiness. She was sitting on $153 million in cash. At 12:37 p.m. Friday, her aides announced that she planned to campaign in Arizona, a state that a Democratic presidential candidate has carried only once since 1948.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: Telecoms’ Ambitions on Targeted Ads Seen Curbed by F.C.C.’s New Privacy Rules
articles.snippet: AT&T’s and Verizon’s hopes of collecting and analyzing customer data to sell advertising may be dashed if they have to ask customers’ permission.
articles.abstract: AT&T’s and Verizon’s hopes of collecting and analyzing customer data to sell advertising may be dashed if they have to ask customers’ permission.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent years, companies like Verizon and AT&T have made no secret of their ambitions to build online advertising businesses that can take on the behemoths of Silicon Valley.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Twitter’s 4-Year Odyssey With the 6-Second Video App Vine
articles.snippet: Twitter built up Vine to leapfrog Instagram and cultivated star users. But as competition stiffened, and employees and users peeled off, Vine lost its hold.
articles.abstract: Twitter built up Vine to leapfrog Instagram and cultivated star users. But as competition stiffened, and employees and users peeled off, Vine lost its hold.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Twitter bought Vine in 2012, it was a three-man company planning an app of six-second videos that had yet to even launch. Still, Jack Dorsey, Twitter’s co-founder who had pushed for the deal, thought he had found the next big thing in social media — an Instagram with video.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac

articles.headline: F.B.I. Chief James Comey Is in Political Crossfire Again Over Emails
articles.snippet: Mr. Comey faced a dilemma: Inform Congress of the new developments, and be accused of harming Hillary Clinton, or wait, and be accused of lacking transparency.
articles.abstract: Mr. Comey faced a dilemma: Inform Congress of the new developments, and be accused of harming Hillary Clinton, or wait, and be accused of lacking transparency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director, faced a dilemma on Thursday when deputies briefed him about the discovery of a trove of emails that might be linked to the inquiry into Hillary Clinton’s private email server that was closed months ago.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau, Michael S. Schmidt and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: For AT&T Chief, Time Warner Deal Is the Peak of an Ambitious Climb
articles.snippet: Randall Stephenson has a history of staking out risky business propositions, including speaking up on divisive subjects and aggressively going after acquisitions.
articles.abstract: Randall Stephenson has a history of staking out risky business propositions, including speaking up on divisive subjects and aggressively going after acquisitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Randall L. Stephenson, the chief executive of AT&T, could easily be pigeonholed as just another empire-building executive with a white-bread résumé. He is a 56-year-old Republican from Oklahoma atop a 140-year-old company, whose extracurricular highlights include serving as president of the Boy Scouts of America and shaping professional golf as a policy board member for the PGA Tour.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Stark Choice for Syrians in Rebel Areas: ‘Doom’ or the Green Bus
articles.snippet: Distinctive vehicles, once a symbol of national hopes, carry besieged rebels and civilians toward an uncertain fate as they yield land to government forces.
articles.abstract: Distinctive vehicles, once a symbol of national hopes, carry besieged rebels and civilians toward an uncertain fate as they yield land to government forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The lime-green buses once ferried Syrians to school, work and dates at Damascus cafes. Now they pull up at moments of defeat, when rebel fighters and civilians, besieged and bombarded, give up their territory to government forces and board the vehicles en route to an uncertain future.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Hwaida Saad

articles.headline: Doubts About the Promised Bounty of Genetically Modified Crops
articles.snippet: Higher yields with less pesticides was the sales pitch for genetically modified seeds. But that has not proved to be the outcome in the United States.
articles.abstract: Higher yields with less pesticides was the sales pitch for genetically modified seeds. But that has not proved to be the outcome in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The controversy over genetically modified crops has long focused on largely unsubstantiated fears that they are unsafe to eat.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Strongly Discouraged Comey on Move in Clinton Email Case
articles.snippet: Senior officials warned the F.B.I. director on policies against talking about current criminal investigations or being seen as meddling in elections.
articles.abstract: Senior officials warned the F.B.I. director on policies against talking about current criminal investigations or being seen as meddling in elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day before the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, sent a letter to Congress announcing that new evidence had been discovered that might be related to the completed Hillary Clinton email investigation, the Justice Department strongly discouraged the step and told him that he would be breaking with longstanding policy, three law enforcement officials said on Saturday.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Adam Goldman, Michael S. Schmidt and William K. Rashbaum

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Assails James Comey, Calling Email Decision ‘Deeply Troubling’
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton’s campaign opened a coordinated attack on Mr. Comey, the F.B.I. director, accusing him of smearing her with innuendo late in the race.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s campaign opened a coordinated attack on Mr. Comey, the F.B.I. director, accusing him of smearing her with innuendo late in the race.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and her allies sprang onto a war footing on Saturday, opening a ferocious attack on the F.B.I.’s director, James B. Comey, a day after he disclosed that his agency was looking into a potential new batch of messages from her private email server.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: N.S.A. Appears to Have Missed ‘Big Red Flags’ in Suspect’s Behavior
articles.snippet: Harold T. Martin III kept his security clearance despite a record that included drinking problems, unpaid tax bills and an episode in which he posed as a police officer.
articles.abstract: Harold T. Martin III kept his security clearance despite a record that included drinking problems, unpaid tax bills and an episode in which he posed as a police officer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Year after year, both in his messy personal life and his brazen theft of classified documents from the National Security Agency, Harold T. Martin III put to the test the government’s costly system for protecting secrets.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Jo Becker

articles.headline: Peter Thiel Defends His Most Contrarian Move Yet: Supporting Trump
articles.snippet: The tech billionaire is known for bucking convention, but his backing of Mr. Trump’s presidential bid has outraged much of Silicon Valley.
articles.abstract: The tech billionaire is known for bucking convention, but his backing of Mr. Trump’s presidential bid has outraged much of Silicon Valley.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Peter Thiel likes to take the path not taken. He has paid students to drop out of college, thinks Silicon Valley is overrated, backed a plan to build cities on the high seas and helped propel an electronic form of money into general use. His contrarian approach to investing and to life has made him rich and celebrated.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld

articles.headline: Media’s Odd Couple: Proudly Freewheeling HBO and Buttoned-Up AT&T
articles.snippet: The telecom giant says it will not interfere with the network, which embraces sex and violence and spends money at will. But the union might not be that simple.
articles.abstract: The telecom giant says it will not interfere with the network, which embraces sex and violence and spends money at will. But the union might not be that simple.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can an elite, free-spending TV network based in Manhattan find a comfortable home at a Dallas telecommunications company led by an executive who is also the Boy Scouts of America president?
articles.byline: By John Koblin

articles.headline: A Little-Noticed Fact About Trade: It’s No Longer Rising
articles.snippet: There are signs that the slowdown is becoming structural. Developed nations appear to be backing away from globalization.
articles.abstract: There are signs that the slowdown is becoming structural. Developed nations appear to be backing away from globalization.
articles.lead_paragraph: The constant flow of goods from Asia to the United States was briefly interrupted last month after Hanjin, the South Korean shipping line, filed for bankruptcy, stranding several dozen of its cargo ships on the high seas.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum

articles.headline: Justice Department Obtains Warrant to Review Clinton Aide’s Emails
articles.snippet: Investigators hope to review as many of Huma Abedin’s emails as possible before Election Day, though it remained unclear whether they could finish their work by then.
articles.abstract: Investigators hope to review as many of Huma Abedin’s emails as possible before Election Day, though it remained unclear whether they could finish their work by then.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal investigators have obtained a warrant to begin searching a large cache of emails belonging to a top aide to Hillary Clinton, law enforcement officials said on Sunday, as prosecutors and F.B.I. agents scrambled under intense public pressure to assess their significance before Election Day.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Michael S. Schmidt and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Black Voters, Aghast at Trump, Find a Place of Food and Comfort
articles.snippet: The struggling African-Americans who visit a Philadelphia food pantry recoil at Donald Trump’s appeals to voters hit hard by economic troubles.
articles.abstract: The struggling African-Americans who visit a Philadelphia food pantry recoil at Donald Trump’s appeals to voters hit hard by economic troubles.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Natalie Solomon was always an early riser. Back in her days at a Ford-owned auto electronics plant, managing production schedules and bringing in $60,000 a year with overtime, she would be behind the wheel of her Ford Explorer by 4 a.m. — in time to grab coffee at Wawa, swing by her locker, grab her smock and get on the factory floor before 5.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Early Turnout Tilts Toward Democrats in Swing States
articles.snippet: Hillary Clinton’s campaign, leveraging its advantage in state-level organization, may be mitigating the fallout from her latest scrap with the F.B.I.
articles.abstract: Hillary Clinton’s campaign, leveraging its advantage in state-level organization, may be mitigating the fallout from her latest scrap with the F.B.I.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has established a slim edge over Donald J. Trump in early-voter turnout in several vital swing states, pressing her longstanding advantages in state-level organization and potentially mitigating the fallout from her campaign’s latest scrap with the F.B.I.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Publishers Are Rethinking Those ‘Around the Web’ Ads
articles.snippet: The ads, which appear mostly via the services Outbrain and Taboola, can lead to questionable websites. Now some publishers wonder about the effect on their readers.
articles.abstract: The ads, which appear mostly via the services Outbrain and Taboola, can lead to questionable websites. Now some publishers wonder about the effect on their readers.
articles.lead_paragraph: You see them everywhere, and maybe, sometimes, you click: those rows of links under web articles, often augmented with eye-catching photos and curiosity-stoking headlines about the latest health tips, celebrity news or ways to escape financial stress.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and John Herrman

articles.headline: Wife and Running Mate: A Real-Life ‘House of Cards’ in Nicaragua
articles.snippet: Rosario Murillo, President Daniel Ortega’s wife, has risen by winning over the poor and the public, but also by pushing out many in Mr. Ortega’s inner circle.
articles.abstract: Rosario Murillo, President Daniel Ortega’s wife, has risen by winning over the poor and the public, but also by pushing out many in Mr. Ortega’s inner circle.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAGUA, Nicaragua — She started out as a teenage mother working as a newspaper secretary, then spent decades of revolution, conflict, power and public scandal at the side of one of the region’s most influential men.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles

articles.headline: The Stakes Are Rising in Google’s Antitrust Fight With Europe
articles.snippet: The search giant is fighting three antitrust charges, and the results will have a major impact on both the tech company and European policy makers.
articles.abstract: The search giant is fighting three antitrust charges, and the results will have a major impact on both the tech company and European policy makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google is locked in a six-year battle with Europe's antitrust officials. And the stakes for both sides are getting higher.
articles.byline: By Mark Scott

articles.headline: Seeking Ownership of Both the Information and the Superhighway
articles.snippet: The AT&T-Time Warner merger raises concerns about the combination of a huge wireless company with a major movie studio and popular cable channels.
articles.abstract: The AT&T-Time Warner merger raises concerns about the combination of a huge wireless company with a major movie studio and popular cable channels.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the face of it, there is something Strangelovian about the proposed merger between AT&T and Time Warner.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg
